Content: Sorry for the dumb question  ,

Author: smellycouch#3071
Content: How many notaries would need to collude to create a problem?

Author: smellycouch#3071
Content: Or is 51 the maximum number that can be turned off?

Author: smellycouch#3071
Content: I read conflicting collusion values in different places...  51, and 30 something

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 51 would need to go "on strike" to prevent notarizations from happening

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries cant just make up random data to notarize as it is validated by all nodes, so their power is limited to witholding of notarization

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: however, independent of notarization power, notaries also get to easy mine 75% of the blocks, so 2/3rds of notaries colluding could do a 51%, that would be 42 notaries needed

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content:
@kimmel (Pungo.io) 
I did some checks for you, you are not in `recvmask` of these nodes:
`
"artik_EU"ca333_EU","chainmakers_NA","etszombi_EU","indenodes_EU","komodoninja_SH","libscott_SH","popcornbag_AR","popcornbag_NA","titomane_SH"]`

I have filtered out the nodes that are not in my recvmask or dwy's recvmask. This is a small sample size of just one BTC rotation. But clearly the issue is in some kind of network route, like Decker was having before. Sorry for pointing you in the wrong direction yesterday, it should not be an issue with your UTXO's or deamon's being down.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I have experianced the odd round where I am also just not recognised in `recvmask` seems to be a network issue, due to where our nodes are. Both are quite the distance from most other nodes.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Checked a few more rounds, and the list is not changing. Maybe contact your Data Centre. You might need to contact those operators and get the IP address of their nodes to check better. Hope this helps.

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: @SHossain @Decker I'm not sure how well that benchmark actually represents real word performance

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I think for a lot of those SIMD style instruction sets you need to be doing constant computation to get the benefits

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: lighting all cores up 100% doing SHA256 will give you a big perf boost

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: just doing one hash every now and then like with iguana may not give much of a boost

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: could even decrease perf

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: due to potential throttling when using advanced instruction sets

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: i like your idea about the option to integrate `./m_notary -sha256=AVX`. that would give operators to test the difference and choose the one that works best for them

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: yeah, it would definitely be interesting to test
